importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks when the White House announced its plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown, highlighting a key development in federal food aid policy amid legislative impasse.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fiscal year 2026 budget cycle began on October 1, 2025, and the government shutdown disrupted funding for WIC, prompting the White House to propose a temporary use of tariff revenue to keep the program operational.

keyTakeAways: The White House announced it would redirect tariff revenue—specifically from Section 32, which traditionally supports child nutrition programs—to fund WIC during the government shutdown.
The proposed funding relies on a congressional measure to designate tariff revenue for WIC, as funds are currently frozen without appropriation.
WIC serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children and is at risk of shutting down due to lack of funding.
The National WIC Association and budget experts question the legality and long-term viability of the tariff funding plan, citing lack of congressional authorization.
The plan has bipartisan support, with House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for shutting down government programs that benefit vulnerable families.
Despite previous funding of $7.6 billion in FY2025, advocates argue WIC needs more funding to maintain enrollment and avoid benefit cuts.
Section 232 tariffs, which are imposed for national security reasons, have generated $190 billion in revenue this year and were initially considered as a source of emergency funds.
WIC provides critical food and nutrition support, including infant formula, baby food, and breastfeeding services, and enrollment has increased due to improved access and rising inflation.
A potential long-term issue is that federal funding for WIC is capped, and without renewed investment, the program may face instability even after the shutdown ends.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive branch of the U.S. federal government, responsible for policy and administration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced and implemented a plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the shutdown, demonstrating executive action in response to legislative inaction.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is one of the journalists who reported on the White House’s decision to redirect tariff revenue to WIC.

namedEntities.name: Samantha Waldenberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She co-authored the news article and reported on the development of the tariff funding proposal for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Karoline Leavitt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She announced the tariff funding plan in a social media post, framing it as a response to Democratic-led government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Section 32
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A component of U.S. tariff law that funds child nutrition programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House proposed using Section 32 revenue to fund WIC during the shutdown, altering its traditional use.

namedEntities.name: Section 232
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A section of U.S. law allowing tariffs to be imposed on goods for national security reasons.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Initially, the administration considered using Section 232 revenue, but later shifted to Section 32 funds for WIC, indicating policy refinement.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program for low-income pregnant women, new mothers, and young children.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is at risk of shutdown due to lack of funding and has become a central issue in the political debate over government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An advocacy group representing WIC participants and state agencies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The association expressed concerns about the transparency and long-term stability of the tariff-funded solution.

namedEntities.name: Georgia Machell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CEO of the National WIC Association.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the temporary funding plan for lacking clarity on funding amount, delivery speed, and duration.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He challenged the legality of the administration's move to use tariff revenue without congressional appropriation.

namedEntities.name: House Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head of the U.S. House of Representatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown, claiming it disrupted WIC and other vital programs.

namedEntities.name: Chuck Schumer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was cited by House Speaker Johnson as a political figure behind the shutdown decision.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: First reported the White House's effort to use tariff revenue to fund WIC.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for implementing and managing WIC programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA informed state agencies that WIC funding had lapsed and provided guidance on contingency funds and state-level alternatives.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States (during second term).
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has been responsible for increasing tariffs and is central to the policy environment that enables the use of tariff revenue for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Fiscal Year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. federal budget period beginning October 1, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The shutdown occurred during this year’s budget cycle, triggering the funding crisis for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Infant formula manufacturers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Private companies that produce infant formula.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: States can use rebates from these manufacturers to offset WIC funding shortfalls.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the 2025 government shutdown, the White House announced it would use Section 32 tariff revenue—typically dedicated to child nutrition—to keep the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC) operational. WIC, which supports nearly 7 million vulnerable families, faced a funding lapse due to Congress’s failure to pass a fiscal year 2026 spending bill. While the White House claims the plan is a ‘creative solution,’ experts and advocacy groups question its legality and long-term stability, noting that Congress has not formally appropriated funds. The decision has drawn bipartisan political attention, with House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for shutting down essential programs. Despite the temporary fix, advocates stress that long-term, sustainable funding is needed to ensure continued access to nutrition support amid rising food costs and increased enrollment.
title: White House to Use Tariff Revenue to Fund WIC During Government Shutdown
